item.title: On full-stack development
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Abramini
item.content:encoded:
From an ignorant frontend developerâ€™s point ofÂ view

I personally thought a developer, to be considered â€˜full-stackâ€™, needed to have a deep knowledge, if not to master, both the frontend and backendÂ worlds.

However, reading around the web, I get that this is not the correct definition.

As this very detailed articleÂ says:

Being a Full-Stack Developer doesnâ€™t mean that you have necessarily mastered everything required to work with the front-end or back-end, but it means that you are able to work on both sides and understand what is going on when building an application.

But if this is the right definition, Iâ€™ve a couple ofÂ doubts.

Does this mean a humble FE is not supposed to know â€˜what is going on when building an applicationâ€™Â ?

This is how this definitions sounds to me. And of course something like this cannot be taken seriously. Performance, bundle-sizing, API integration, FE routing, structuring forms are all activities which require a good understanding of the backend world. You donâ€™t understand that, you simply cannot be a good FE developer.

Also, curiosity is a key feature in development. If you reached a good FE knowledge you want to understand whatâ€™s around. I can bet every good FE dev has deployed his node.js server, or, probably more in the past than now, has played with PHP frameworks and app, from Wordpress toÂ Laravel.

I personally have knowledge of Node.js and PHP servers, Linux systems, CI & CD, testing, SQL & noSQL databases. Iâ€™m a not a genius with them, but I can and I enjoy working in these areas. Does this make me a full-stack developer? I donâ€™t think so. Iâ€™m a specialised FE dev with a side knowledge of â€˜what is going on when building an applicationâ€™Â .

How does this fit in a largeÂ team?

I donâ€™tÂ know!

I reckon being able to tackle all the aspects of developing an application can be very useful in a small startup where the business cannot afford specialised roles. Or as well, it could be a very useful set of skills for a technical manager to scope and organise projects.

However, for example, if my team has to take care of several frontend features and Iâ€™ve to distribute these tasks in an Agile environment, Iâ€™d prefer to rely on strong, specialised teammates. Wouldnâ€™t you do theÂ same?

Iâ€™ve the feeling a fullstack developer knows how to do it, but maybe doesnâ€™t know the best way to do it. There are so many things to know on both the front and the back ends of web development, a person cannot simply know all ofÂ them.

I donâ€™t mean to offend anyone, Iâ€™m just eager to find someone able to clarify myÂ doubts.

If anyone reads this and has a different point of view, please, I mean it - please!, let meÂ know!

item.title: Angular2 . Quick ref notes | part 3
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Abramini
item.content:encoded:
Custom directives, services andÂ routes

Custom directives

When creating a new directive you can use this two powerful decorators: @HostBinding and @HostListener decorators:

HostBinding bind an element property to a directive property. For instance:

@HostBinding('class.open') isOpen:Boolean = false

binds the â€˜openâ€™ class to the boolean property isOpen. Setting this property to true will add the class the htmlÂ element.

HostListener bind an element event to a directive method. For instance:

@HostListener('click') handleClick() {
   ...
}

will make your directive listening to the â€˜clickâ€™ events on the host html element and wil trigger the newly defined handleClick method whenever the clickÂ happens.

In the directive constructor you have access to at least these 2 propsÂ :

private elRef: ElementRef, private renderer: Renderer2

elRef contains the actual element in its nativeElement property.

Services

Services is common code used in several components that doesnâ€™t have influence over the DOM elements of the components. Itâ€™s used by them but it doesnt belong to them. (es. store and fetchÂ data).

A service is a simple ts class. It can have properties and methods. However, to have it instanciated, donâ€™t use the newÂ keyword.

Instead, in your component main decorator, add the providers property assigned to an array containing your serviceÂ class.

@Component({
  selector: 'app-component',
  providers: [MyService]
})

Secondly, define a myService property of the type of your service in the component constructor.

constructor(private myService:MyService) { }

However

Depending on where you instantiate this component, the instance will be available to a different audience.

If you instantiate it on the AppModule, the instance will be available to all the modules and services.

If you instantiate it on the AppComponent, the instance will be available to all the modules but not the services.

If you instantiate it on the a child component, the instance will be available to the component and its children.

So

Usually you probably want to add the service in the provider only once, generally speaking in the AppModule. To access it, just pass the type in the constructor of your component.

To inject services in otherÂ services

Remember to add in to the receiver service the @Injectable decorator.
Thatâ€™sÂ it!

Routing

Setup

To setup the routes, create an array of type Routes, imported from @angular/router and assign to it objects with a path and a component property.

Then, add it to the imports array in the NgModule decorator, invoking the forRoot function with the routes array as parameter.

import { RouterModule, Routes } from "@angular/router";

const routes: Routes = [
    { path: '', component: HomeComponent },
    { path: 'about-us', component: AboutComponent },
];

@NgModule({
    declarations: [
        AppComponent,
        HomeComponent,
        AboutComponent,
    ],
    imports: [
        BrowserModule,
        RouterModule.forRoot(routes)
    ],

Step 2 is to add the directiveâ€Šâ€”â€Šplaceholder that updates its content with a module we specified in the routes, when the path matches, in your app html template.

<router-outlet></router-outlet>

Links inÂ template

To use a link within the router logic, add a routerLink attribute with the new url. Remember, the link is relative to the view where the linkÂ lies.

<a routerLink="/about-us">About us</a>

Provide router activeÂ class

To make the About Us link active when the url of the page is the same of the routerLink, use the routerLinkActive set to the name of the active class you want toÂ give.

<a routerLink="/about-us"
   routerLinkActive="is-active">About us</a>

This directive however just checks if the provided link matches the url. For instance, the previous example would match also something like
/about-us/hello

To prevent this from happening, you should also specify someÂ options

<a routerLink="/about-us"
   routerLinkActive="is-active"
   [routerLinkActiveOptions]="{exact: true}">About us</a>

Navigate programmatically

You can access the Router directly from the tsÂ file.

constructor(
    private router: Router
)

And use theÂ .navigate method from the newly defined router function.

this.router.navigate(['/about-us'])

If you are in a nested component (see later for more details), you may want to add an extra paramenter to the function that define what the new url has to be relativeÂ to.

this.router.navigate([this.product.id], { relativeTo: this.route })

Dynamic routes

To access a dynamic router, lets first define one with the following syntax.

const routes: Routes = [
    { path: '/user/:id', component: UserComponent },
];

Now the component UserComponent wil be activated once you navigate to something like /user/110.

To access that id from the code, youâ€™ll need to get the activatedRoute from the constructor:

constructor(
    private route: ActivatedRoute
) {

And access it in the method you need reading the params of the snapshot object of the routeÂ object.

ngOnInit() {
    this.id = this.route.snapshot.params['id']
}

This solution works fine when the component is first loaded. However, if the path parameters changes, you need a way to dinamically update your properties. Using a subscribing to the params observable will do theÂ trick.

ngOnInit() {
    this.route.params
       .subscribe(
          (params: Params) => {
             this.id = params.id
          }
       );
}

Query parameters andÂ hashes

To setup a router link with some query parameters user the queryParams directive on the aÂ tag:

<a
   [routerLink]="['user', 30]"
   [queryParams]="{isAdmin: 1}"
>
   my Link    
</a>

The new url will be resolved in /user/30?isAdmin=1Â .

To add an hash, or more technically a fragment, use the, guess what?, fragment directive.

<a
   [routerLink]="['user', 30]"
   fragment="about"
>
   my Link
</a>

The new url will be resolved in /user/30#aboutÂ .

To achieve this programmatically, just pass some options to the navigate method ofÂ router.

this.router.navigate(['user', 30], {
        queryParams: {
            isAdmin: 1,
        },
        fragment: 'intro'
    })

To get this values from the url, you can do something very similar to what we did for the parameters. So:

ngOnInit() {
    this.route.snapshot.queryParams
    this.route.queryParams.subscribe()

    this.route.snapshot.fragment
    this.route.fragment.subscribe()
}

To keep the current query parameters on new links with the navigate method, you may want to use the queryParamsHandling option set to â€˜preserveâ€™. To merge with new ones, set that property toÂ â€˜mergeâ€™.

this.router.navigate(['user', 30], {
    queryParamsHandling: 'preserve'
})

Nested routes

To user nested routes you have first to define their structure in the main app module. Letâ€™s add, for example a products route. From there we want to be able to see single product from as children of the ProductsComponentÂ . So we have to specify the children property as an array of the nestedÂ routes.

const routes: Routes = [
    { path: '', component: HomeComponent },
    { path: 'about-us', component: AboutComponent },
    { path: 'products', component: ProductsComponent, children: [
       { path: ':id', component: SingleProductComponent },
    ]},
];

In the parent component we also have to add a second router-outlet tag to allow the children to be displayed. So in this case we add this to the ProductsComponentÂ .

<router-outlet></router-outlet>

Redirections

Instead of specifying a component in you routes, you can also define an alternative url where to be redirected to. For instance:

const routes: Routes = [
    { path: '', component: HomeComponent },
    { path: 'about-us', component: AboutComponent },
    { path: 'who-we-are', redirectTo: 'about-us' }
];

Itâ€™s good practice to add a pathMatch: â€˜fullâ€™ property to avoid matchingÂ issues.

{ path: 'who-we-are', redirectTo: 'about-us', pathMatch: â€˜fullâ€™ }

Wildcards

To specify wildcards, simply use the double asteriskÂ **

const routes: Routes = [
    { path: '', component: HomeComponent },
    { path: 'about-us', component: AboutComponent },
    { path: '**', component: 'NotFound'}
];

item.title: Angular2 . Quick ref notes | part 2
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Abramini
item.content:encoded:
Relationships between components

Passing external properties to component

Step 1

Using the Input decorator, make your component aware of this coming-in property. You can also pass an optional parameter to add to change the [myProp] name in the template (myPropAlias in the example).

class MyComponent {
   @Input('myPropAlias') myProp;
   constructor() { }
}

Step 2

You can now match this property with an external one in the html template.

<app-my-component
   [myPropAlias]="myExternalProp"
>
</app-my-component>

Dispatching events to parent components

When you have the necessity for a parent component to invoke a method when something specific happens in a child component (MyComponent, in this example), you have to go through 2Â steps.

Step 1

Define the event inside the component class. Youâ€™ll have to import the EventEmitter class and the Output Decorator from @angular/core

Step 2

Now wherever you use this component, you can hook the parentâ€™s methods to your new component event.

The $event object holds the events data: pass it as a parameter to make it available to the invokedÂ methods.

Referencing DOM elements in theÂ template

If you want to have a particular html element of your html template in your typescript code, you may want to use a local reference #.

At this point we are able to get the newly referenced element into my ts code as parameter of the doSomething method.

If you want to have access to a local reference before the methods, there is another way to achieve this. This is via the ViewChild decorator.

Passing complex html content to a component

To pass actual HTML content inside a component in thisÂ way:

<app-my-component>
  <h1>My title</h1>
  <h2>My subtitle</h2>

  <ul>
    <li>Even</li>
    <li>a</li>
    <li>list</li>
  </ul>
</app-my-component>

You just have to make sure that in your MyComponent template you have the ng-content directive

<div class="my-content">
  <p class="my-content-intro">Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. Ad cumque deleniti molestias nam, optio provident.</p>
  <ng-content></ng-content>
</div>

Referencing DOM elements in ng-content

If you want to refer to the code inside ng-content, you can simply repeat the steps we saw earlier for DOM access. The only difference is not to use the @ViewChild decorator but @ViewContent.

Components Lifecycle Hooks

Every component has to go through different stages when built, changed and destroyed. Angular gives us hooks to allow us to call our methods during thoseÂ stages.

Just remember to import these interfaces from @angular/core when usingÂ them.

I could rewrite them here, but for the sake of briefness, Iâ€™ll just refer you to the official documentation https://angular.io/guide/lifecycle-hooks#lifecycle-sequence.

This is more or less everything about components. Iâ€™m about to start taking a deep dive into directives, always with this amazing course on Udemy. I warmly suggest you to give it aÂ check!

This article is part of my journey in learning Angular4. Hereâ€™s the other articles:

  • Step 1. Components overview
  • Step 2. Relationships between components

item.title: Introduction to Frontend Javascript testing
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Abramini
item.content:encoded:
A introductory, framework-agnostic article about how, what and when toÂ test.

ğŸ““ Intro

So many times we all wrote Javascript components and so many times we had to modify, change, extend them. Sometimes they are not very complicated; sometimes the change request arrives during the same project phase; sometimes we remember how and in which scenarios the component works; sometimes we had had time to implement meaningful error messages; sometimes we are the authors of these components.

Other times, we are inÂ trouble.

When is JS testingÂ useful?

Generally speaking, once you have implemented a series of tests these are always good to have. However, there are situations where you would sacrifice you hamster to have hadÂ them.

  1. Your component/code is getting complicated.
    Is that line of code really necessary? In which scenario does my component requires this css class to work? Complexity prevents us to see all the consequences of our actions, we need some extra help to make sure everything will continue working after our modification.
  2. You have to edit a component you written months or years ago.
    Sometimes, while coding, it seems obvious what a function does and what those variables mean. Of course, if you are a good developer, youâ€™d use meaningful names and, when necessary, youâ€™d add some comments.
    However, sometimes these are not enough and if you are changing some very old code what seemed obvious now is an enigma. Let the testing tools helpÂ you!
  3. You have to edit a component someone else wrote.
    See situation #2

How does testing actuallyÂ work?

To test you need a testing suite or framework. Iâ€™m going to use Jest: I like it because itâ€™s a complete suite and Iâ€™m used to it for testing React apps. Other great test frameworks are Jasmine andÂ Mocha.

  1. Install the framework viaÂ npm.
  2. Have a componentToTest.test.js file (or componentToTest.spec.js).
  3. Insert some tests in thisÂ file.
  4. Run the framework viaÂ console.

While the steps 1, 2 and 4 are dead simple, once you check the documentation of the testing suite, step #3 is definitely the most interesting.

There are different types of tests, but lets first start with a simpleÂ one.

Example #1

Lets say we have a function in a utilities.js file.

export function removeUnderscores(myString) {
    return myString.replace(/_/g, '');
}

At this point we want to make sure this function works and will alwaysÂ work.

In our utilities.spec.js we need now to create a test in thisÂ way

import { removeUnderscores } from './utilities';
describe('Testing my utilities', () => {
  test('removeUnderscores actually removes underscores', () => {
    expect(removeUnderscores('blah_blah_blah'))
      .toEqual('blahblahblah');
  });
});

Once setup a test like this, run the test suite in the consoleÂ andâ€¦

Thatâ€™s of course a very simple test, but now if someone changes and breaks that function youâ€™ll knowÂ itÂ beforeÂ itâ€™s tooÂ late!

The syntax

As we saw in the previous test, we nees to use some particular functions like describe, test, expect, in order to have things done. These functions comes with your testÂ suite.

They slightly change between frameworks, but letâ€™s see what the generically do.

describe(description, func)

This function is used to wrap groups of tests together and organise them under a readably title. NothingÂ else.

test (description, func)

test() or it() is the container for the actual test. It describes what it contains and it runs allnthe assertions inside the callback.

expect(object)

expect() is the first element of an assertion. It requires the object of the assertion as parameters and it has to concatenated to other functions that complete theÂ process.

These other functions come from some of the test suites or you may add extra assertion libraries to achieve the result you want. For example Mocha requires the library Chai to make assertions.

An example about functional testing

Example #1 is a typical unit testing exampleâ€Šâ€”â€Šwe make sure a function, the smallest unit in a module, with a given parameter returns a specificÂ result.

Functional testing is about simulate the component behaviour and double-check that everything goes how it should during this path. Letâ€™s check anÂ example:

Example #2â€Šâ€”â€ŠSmall navigation toggle

Lets pretend we have a small mainNav component. This script will look for a specific element in the DOM and, if it finds, it will listen for a click on a children button. Hereâ€™s the code forÂ mainNav.

If you checked the code you may have noticed mainNavâ€™s button, once clicked, does a couple ofÂ things.

  1. It switches its label from â€˜Open menuâ€™ to â€˜Close menuâ€™ and viceÂ versa
  2. It adds and removes theÂ .is-hidden class from the contentÂ element

Now that we know what it does, letâ€™s make sure itÂ works!

Give a check to the code below, Iâ€™ll describe itÂ after.

First, lets make sure we have our class imported.

Now with the beforeAll function (I think thatâ€™s pretty clear what it does) letâ€™s simulate the document.body content with the required code and create the instance.

I first like to create a empty tests that stops if our component returns errors on construction [Itâ€™s initialised withoutÂ errors].

Letâ€™s check our first functional test [Click on button changes button text].We trigger a first click with the vanilla js function click and we expect the new button.text to be equal to the static class property labels.close. Triggering another click, we expect the label to be equal to labels.open. It if fails to do so for any reasons, now the test will make us aware ofÂ it.

The second test checks whether the content element gets theÂ .is-hidden class on toggleÂ click.

Andâ€¦

This of course is just a brief intro to what is, or should be, actually a very important aspect of frontend development.

Hereâ€™s some other resources you can read to learn more about testing with Javascript:

  1. Unit, functional and integration tests
  2. Intro to test-driven development
  3. Testing React components

ğŸ‘ Clapping is caring!Â â¬‡ï¸

item.title: How to get your Medium posts on your website
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Abramini
item.content:encoded:
A brief tutorial on how to display your latest posts on yourÂ website.

The problem

Some months ago I got the idea to add a blog section to my portfolio: an area where I could share my experiences and learnings. The idea was amazing: create a custom small CMS with Node.js, maybe linked to a MongoDB database. Iâ€™d have also to create a CMS interface, handle the post status and several other things. Although the idea was feasible, it would have also required quite a bit of time to develop and test theÂ code.

At that point I asked myself, why not to use an existing platform? Take Medium, for example: awesome editor, great minimal UI and a cheerful and rich community of users. And so I did choose Medium as media to post and display my, lets say it, mediocreÂ posts.

Eventually however, the idea of displaying the posts on my portfolio pushed its way in my brain once again. I first checked the Medium API, I created an app on the dev platform, only to discover that these APIs are mainly focused on writing posts, more that merely displaying.

Sniffing around google and Stack Overflow I found some guys saying that answer lied in their rss feed: https://medium.com/feed/@username

What did I do than? I got axios in my portfolio React app and shot a quick GET call to the rss feed url: what did I received? An obvious CORS error and a fancy error message from the Medium serverÂ saying:

localhost is not an allowed domain. Our host is (medium.com:443, /feed/@oldirony)

Client side issues! So, letâ€™s focus on how I solve theÂ issue.

The solution

Step 1: Create an Express controller

As we said, I faced these errors because I was trying to get this ajax call from the client. Lets bypass the issue and fetch my posts from theÂ server.

On my Node server, managed by express.js, I first had to create a new controller and refer it to its core file. The chosen route is /get-posts, so once the controller is setup I can access oldirony.cc/get-posts via GET to receive a json object with my MediumÂ posts.

import getPostsController from './server/get-posts';

server.get('/get-posts', getPostsController);

In get-posts.js, the first thing youâ€™ve to do is to export as default the controller function:

export default (req, res) => {
   res.send('Yeah')
}

Step 2: Fetch posts viaÂ Node

At this point, we have to make the actual GET request. I used axios as library to fetch the posts, as I already had it in my dependencies.

On call success, I send the stringified version of the response data to theÂ page.

import axios from 'axios';
const POSTS_URL = 'https://medium.com/feed/@oldirony';

export default (req, res) => {
   axios.get(POSTS_URL)
      .then(response => {
         res.end(JSON.stringify(response.data))
      })
      .catch(err => res.end(err));
}

Step 3: Convert posts from XML toÂ JSON

Yes, Itâ€™s not finished yet. I found on the internet people suggesting to appendÂ ?format=json to the endpoint url to get the data in a JSON format, but, I donâ€™t know why, it didnâ€™t work forÂ me.

So, as the documentation is almost inexistent, I chose another solution.

Using the xml2js library, I parsed the string using its own function parseString and I sent back to the page the stringified list of articles res2.rss.channel[0].itemÂ .

import axios from 'axios';
import { parseString } from 'xml2js';
const POSTS_URL = 'https://medium.com/feed/@oldirony';

export default (req, res) => {
   axios.get(POSTS_URL)
      .then(response => {
         parseString(response.data, (err, res2) =>{
            res.end(JSON.stringify(res2.rss.channel[0].item))
         })
      })
      .catch(response => res.end(response.data));
}

Step 4: Get posts to the actual websiteÂ page

Now that we got our list of posts of our Node server we can easily access them from ourÂ page.

Iâ€™m using React and Redux on portfolio, so what I did was to setup an action creator that fetches from our predefined route â€˜/get-postsâ€™ on a specific homepage section onMountÂ event.

This, anyway, is the essential code:

import axios from 'axios';
const POSTS_URL = '/get-posts';

export function fetchPosts() {
   return function(dispatch) {
      axios.get(POSTS_URL).then((response) => {
         // Here response.data contains an array with your 
         // most recent posts.
      })
   }
}

And this is it! For any question, just drop a line in the comments.

item.title: Angular2. Quick ref notes | part 1
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Abramini
item.content:encoded:
Angular2Â . Quick ref notes | partÂ 1

Component overview

So I started learning Angular4! It looks like an interesting journey: Iâ€™m having the chance to see how another dev team solves the typical issues that a js framework faces.

I listed here the first part of my learnings. You can use this a quick reference guide.

Components

Components are the most basic element of the apps. These are the Lego bricks what will compose your engine. These elements will contain their own JS logic, html structure andÂ styles.

To create a component you can either run this command in theÂ console:

ng generate component componentName

Or this, with a more compactÂ syntax:

ng g c componentName

Or create follow this steps to create a component manually:

1. Create the mainÂ .tsÂ file

Create a componentName/componentName.component.ts file. In here, simply define the class that is going to give shape to your component and exportÂ it.

export class ComponentNameComponent {
   constructor(){}
}

Also, remember to set this class up with the boilerplate structure of a component with a decorator. Import the decorator function from angular and define the minimal settings, selector and templateUrl (or template).

import { Component } from '@angular/core';


@Component({
    selector: 'app-component-name',
    templateUrl: './header.component.html'
})
export class ComponentNameComponent {
    constructor() {}

}
  • selector defines the way you can invoke this component in your app. It can be an HTML selector (default), an attribute or event aÂ class.
  • templateUrl define the path to the html template of the component.
  • or template allows you to define an inline html template (useful for small components)

There are a lot of other properties you can define from here. They are listedÂ here.

2. Create the html templateÂ file.

If you specified the templateUrl property, youâ€™ll need also to add this templateÂ file.

3. Include component in the appÂ module

In the app.module.ts file, import your newly created component with an import statement and add it in the declarations array of you appÂ module.

import { ComponentNameComponent } from './header/header.component';

@NgModule({
  declarations: [
    AppComponent,
    ComponentNameComponent
  ],
  imports: [
    BrowserModule
  ],
  providers: [],
  bootstrap: [AppComponent]
})
export class AppModule { }

Decorators

Template syntax

Property binding in templates with [ ]. You can edit all the js properties of the DOMÂ element.

[disabled]=â€œisDisabledâ€

Event binding in templates with ().Â Ie

(click)=â€œmyEvent()â€;

Standard directives as two ways data binding* using ngModel directive on anÂ input.

[(ngModel)]=â€œpropNameâ€
  • For 2 ways Data Binding, FormsModule should be included in the appÂ module.

Structural directives requires * in the syntax. It handles the structure of the DOM element, not only properties. For instance:

<div *ngIf="isVisible"></div>

Local reference #

Directives

Directives are instructions in the DOM. Usually the selector is an attribute. Defined with the @Directive decorator.

If/else conditionals

To use a simple if statement use

*ngIf=â€conditionâ€

To use the else in the conditional we need to create a local reference with #, add an ng-template with that reference and enhance the ngIf condition with it. For instance:

<p *ngIf=â€isDefined; else #notDefinedâ€>It's defined!</p>
<ng-template #notDefined>
    <p>Not defined</p>
<ng-template>

Conditional style

Use [ngStyle] equal to an object of styles to customise the style of an element. For instance:

<div [ngStyle]="{backgroundColor: getBgColor()}">

NB. The kebab-case of the css props becomes camelCase.

Conditional classes

Use [ngClass] to conditionally setÂ classes

<div [ngClass]="{isActive: isActive()}">

For eachÂ loops

Use the structural directive ngFor.

<div *ngFor="let item of items">

You can access the index prop in thisÂ fashion:

<div *ngFor="let item of items; let i of index">

Typekit

Variables type restriction

Typescript gives you the possibility of enforcing the type of the variables. Something similar to what you can (and should) do with propTypes inÂ React.

First things first, when you create a class, you have to initialise the properties you are going to use later on. For instance:

class MyClass {
    public title: string;
    public id: number;

    constructor() { }
}

Define variable type on declaration usingÂ :Â . ForÂ instance

myStringVar: string = â€˜Text textâ€™

To define a variable as array of something, in this case an array ofÂ strings:

myArray: string[] = ['server1', 'server2'];

Define inline variable type with <type>myVar. You may want to use brackets.

(<HTMLInputElement>event.target).value

Models

As you know Angular2+ relies on typescript for internal code validation. Therefore, not surprisingly, Angular models are pure TSÂ classes.

A model consists in a TS class where we define the required and possible properties. For instance:

export class MyModel {
    public name: string;
    public description: string;

    constructor(name: string, desc: string) {
        this.name = name;
        this.description = desc;
    }
}

This is as more compactÂ syntax:

export class MyModel {
    constructor(public name: string, public description: string) {}     
}

This code will allow us to generate valid Recipes with typescript. To do this, just import the model and use to validateÂ objects:

import { MyModel } from "../myModel.model";
[...]
export class RecipeListComponent implements OnInit {
  recipes: MyModel[] = [];

This article is part of my journey in learning Angular4. Hereâ€™s the other articles:

  • Step 1. Components overview
  • Step 2. Relationships between components

Let me stop you here. This is not a tutorial article or anything similar. Iâ€™m just collecting my first impressions on Angular4 to see how (and if) these change as I get to know more of this framework.

Iâ€™ve been working with React for a couple of years now and I find it elegant, efficient and, once you get to know it, very easy to integrate andÂ extend.

However, I cannot ignore the fact that there are a lot of people who, for one reason or another, support Angular2 (that now has become Angular4).

I decided therefore to start exploring and learning it: this will allow me to have a more objective vision of these frameworks and when to use one or another. You know, knowledge is power. Learning will give you the chance of really comparing frameworks! How can you say something is better that something else, if you donâ€™t know one of the comparison terms?

How can you say something is better that something else, if you donâ€™t know one of the comparison terms?

I had already followed several courses on Udemy, so i decided to look for something to get started. The one I chose isÂ thisÂ one: https://www.udemy.com/the-complete-guide-to-angular-2/.

First impressions

ğŸ‘ CliÂ based

Iâ€™ve been working with the CLI for 3 years now and I consider it an utmost invaluable (and indispensable) friend in my day to day work. The fact that to create and run even the most basic angular projectÂ requiresÂ thisÂ tool, is for me a very goodÂ sign.

ğŸ‘ Typescript

I love the idea of having a tool that enforce the code while you write it. Even if it takes a tiny bit longer to have your script written, Typescript makes sure that your code is used in the way you want. If my parameter numberOfFishes is supposed to a number, I want it to always be a number. If a colleague of mine invokes that function with numberOfFishes set as â€˜nopeâ€™, Iâ€™d like to throw something at himâ€Šâ€” better if that something is anÂ error.

âœ‹ Modules

About this, i havenâ€™t quite enjoyed or, to be honest, completely understood, the need of specifying modules. For example, why do i have to invoke the FormModule to insert an inputÂ andÂ bindingÂ it? I suppose this is to keep the bundle size to the bare minimum. However,Â meh!

âœ‹ Templating syntax

Iâ€™m not quite amused by not being able to freely insert js in the templates and, instead, having to learn a quite specific syntax as, for instance, [(ngModule)]=â€œmyPropâ€.

Once again, the one writing is only someone who has used this framework for no more than half anÂ hour.

Iâ€™m writing a follow-up article as I study and experience Angular4. Iâ€™ll put the link in hereâ€¦ for anyone who managed to pass over this bunch of groundless opinions.

item.title: Tales from another js MVC framework â€” pt .1
item.dc:creator: Raffaele Abramini
item.content:encoded:
Some weeks ago, talking with a friend of mine, we started imagining how difficult would be to create an MVC framework from scratch and which difficulties we could encounter. I had a bit of spare time during the following weekend, so I decided to give it aÂ try.

The aim of this experiment was not to create another alternative to React, Vue or Angular2, just to understand better the issues those libraries (and frameworksâ€Šâ€”â€Šok, Angular fans?) solve forÂ us.

Iâ€™m pretty sure Iâ€™ve done it in a way you could consider naiveâ€Šâ€”â€Šbut again, this is just an investigation. Please share your thoughts onÂ this.

You can see the project code onÂ Github.

The name

Not a key part of the project, but I actually found myself wondering about how to name this framework.

Because of lack of ideas, I went for a pretty anonymous Minimal JSÂ MVC

The structure

The idea was to keep it simple. What were the most essential things toÂ have?

  1. A controller
  2. A parser
  3. Something to listen toÂ events
  4. A demoÂ example
  5. A micro server to run theÂ code
  6. Some tests to make sure everything works

Nothing very surprising here.

Because I like React, I imagined the controller as an extendable es6 class. There will be a controller per component.

The view, as well, is defined inside the component in this example. However the view its just a string, so no-one is stopping us from separate that in an anotherÂ file.

In order to make this view usable, we need a logic to parse its content and find which model properties toÂ render.

Lastly it is necessary to have an event handler that extrapolates the different event functions from a view template, identifies them within the controller methods and listens for them once the view itâ€™s recreated in theÂ DOM.

Setup the environment

Iâ€™ve kept a simple Webpack setup with Babel to have support for es6 syntax andÂ modules.

I didnâ€™t use the out-of-the-box Webpack dev server to have more flexibility later on. With hindsight, I could have used itâ€Šâ€” but thatâ€™s life. Maybe iâ€™ll integrate it in theÂ future.

The code

Letâ€™s take a deeper dive into theÂ code.

controller.js

The controller is the keystone of this small library. With this element all the components get extended and initialised.

For aesthetic and usability reasons I wanted the Controller to be used, as I said earlier, as a base for new classes. For instance:

class Article extends Controller {
   constructor(params){
      super(params);
   
      [...]

And actually initialised and renderedÂ with

Article.init(VIEW_TEMPLATE, DOM_SELECTOR)

In order to achieve this I needed to structure the Controller structure in a particular way:

class Controller {
   static init(template, DOMSelector){
      if(!template || !DOMSelector) throw new Error('Please specify template string and DOM selector when instantiating a Controller');

      const instance =new this({
         template,
         DOMSelector
      });

      instance.render();
   }

   constructor({template, DOMSelector}){
      this.template = template;
      this.DOMSelector = DOMSelector;
   }

The static initialiser takes the new class scope and creates a new instance of it with the specified template and DOM selector.

As you can see, the next step is the renderÂ . This is the render method con the controller.

render(){
   const newHTML = parser.parse(this.template, this.properties);
   const DOMElem = document.querySelector(this.DOMSelector);

   if(!DOMElem) throw new Error('Please specify a selector for an existing DOMElement when initialising a controller.');

   DOMElem.innerHTML = newHTML;
   events.listen(DOMElem, this);
}

First thing in the list is creating the parsed view template in the DOM with the component properties.

Now itâ€™s time to check the role that the parser plays in it. Let just remember this render method laterÂ on.

parser.js

The parser js is a simple object of functional-programming-structured methods. The main function is, of course,Â parse.

parse(htmlstring, controllerInstance){
   if(!controllerInstance.__id) controllerInstance.__id =`jsmvc-${id}`;

   let parsedHtmlstring = this._populate(htmlstring, controllerInstance);

   const map = this._mapEventIds(parsedHtmlstring, controllerInstance.__id);
   controllerInstance.__eventsMap = map.eventsMap;

   parsedHtmlstring = map.htmlstring;

   return parsedHtmlstring;
}

What does itÂ do?

  1. Sets the private property __id for the controller instance. We will need this later on to define and listen forÂ events.
  2. Populates the html string with the instance properties
  3. Creates an eventsMap. This object contains both the list of events with the linked id and a second parse of the original htmlÂ string.
  4. Store the eventsMap into the mainÂ instance
  5. Returns the parsedÂ html

Good. Next step is setting up how the eventsÂ work.

Events.js

Going back to the render method of the controls we can see that the parsed view has been returned and rendered into theÂ DOM.

Here the events object is invoked with its main methodÂ .listen

listen(DOMElem, controllerInstance){
   const eventsMap = controllerInstance.properties.__eventsMap;
   eventsMap.forEach(event => {
      if(!this._isFunction(event.method, controllerInstance)) return;

      DOMElem.querySelector(`[_id="${event.id}"]`)
         .addEventListener(
            event.name,
            controllerInstance[event.method].bind(controllerInstance)
         )
   })
}

This method simply loops through the eventsMap object attaching the controller instance methods to the specified listeners.

Soâ€¦

Itâ€™s obviously clear this library itâ€™s not production material. However it has been pretty interesting take a glance to the other side of the day-to-day libraries usage.

Events, one and two ways data-binding, rendering and other aspects that modern js frameworks cover are, in the end, simply js logics and base DOM interactions.

Developers shouldnâ€™t forget that, however refined and intricate, frameworks are not based on magic, but (hopefully) cleverÂ code.

Next steps

Till now Iâ€™ve implemented one-way data-binding, a non rock-solid interaction event system and quick rendering system. Seems obvious itâ€™s not completeÂ yet.

Next challenges couldÂ be:

  • Multiple events on same DOMÂ element
  • Two-ways binding (inputÂ handle)
  • Multiple controllers interaction
  • Routes
